Award.AwardTitle: Conference on Computational Mathematics and Applications (CCAM)
Award.AbstractNarration:
This award provides participant support to Conference on Computational Mathematics and Applications (CCMA), to be held at University of Nevada Las Vegas (UNLV), October 25-27, 2019. Computational Mathematics is a rapidly growing multidisciplinary field lying at the intersection of mathematics and many disciplines of science and engineering. With the increasing of computational technology in recent years, the pivotal role of Computational Mathematics continues to expand to broader areas that include not only the traditional science and engineering, but also social sciences, finance, medical science and data science. In order to disseminate the state-of-the-art computational techniques and put them into broad applications, the organizers propose to host "Conference on Computational Mathematics and Applications (CCMA) at the University of Nevada Las Vegas (UNLV) during October 25-27, 2019. Holding the proposed conference at UNLV will not only provide a strong stimulus for our graduate students and increase the local research activity for mathematicians and people from other related disciplines, it will also serve as a new catalysis for proposing new computational methodology and pointing some new research directions in scientific computing.

This conference will bring many prominent scholars in Computational and Applied Mathematics to address important topics that have fundamental scientific merits and significant application values. Topics to be focused are: "Recent advances in wave propagation and applications", "Numerical methods for stochastic PDEs and applications", "Numerical analysis and modeling of complex fluids", and "Machine Learning for Scientific Computing". The organizers plan to host around 60 participants with 6 invited plenary 50-minute talks, and several parallel sessions of 30-minute talks. The organizers will strive to support about 10 postdocs and junior faculty, especially women and under-represented minorities. The subjects covered in this conference will benefit not only mathematics, but also many other computational related fields such as mechanical engineering, geosciences, physics, and medical sciences. To create a long term impact, a refereed conference proceeding will be published after the conference either as a book in the AMS Contemporary Mathematics series or as a special issue of a computational science journal. More details are available at http://cams.sites.unlv.edu/conferences/ccma2019/ccma2019.html.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Project Outcomes Report – NSF Award 1907169

Project Title: Conference on Computational Mathematics and Applications (CCMA)

Recipient Organization: University of Nevada Las Vegas

Project/Grant Period: 05/15/2019 – 04/30/2021

PI/Co-PI:
        Jichun Li (PI)
        Monika Neda (Co-PI)
        Zhijian Wu (Co-PI)


To provide a new catalysis for exploring the-state-of-the-art computational methodology and research directions in computational mathematics,
we proposed to hold ”Conference on Computational Mathematics and Applications (CCMA)” at The University of Nevada Las Vegas (UNLV).

We, along with other several faculty and 5 PhD students, used our weekend times to hold this conference on UNLV campus during October 25-27 (Friday-Sunday), 2019. The conference attracted about 90 attendees (well
above our proposed plan for 60 attendees) from many prestigeous universities in USA. Topics spanned a wide variety of fields, such as imaging, wave propagation, complex fluids, materials, mathematical finance, optimization,
uncertainty quatification and machine learning. The conference consisted of
4 plenary speakers,  8 minisymposia, and over 70 very interesting talks.
This conference offered a unique opportunity for many young researchers and graduate students (especially people from UNLV) to meet leading researchers in this field and learn the forefront of the main streams in Computational Mathematics.

To make the conference results accessble to broader readers, we published a special issue in the journal "Results in Applied Mathematics" (an open access journal published by Elsevier). With the generous support from Elsevier, the special issue is free of charge for all contributions and published in the Nov. 2020 issue. All 15 high quality papers can be freely downloaded for general public at the journal website (//www.sciencedirect.com/journal/results-in-applied-mathematics/vol/8/suppl/C).

The project was quite successful as evidenced by an overwelming number of
participants including many active researchers, graduate students and junior
faculty. This conference provided a good opportunities for training and professional development for young faculty and graduate students. Two of UNLV PhD students talked their research in the conference and worked as Postdoc fellows after they earned their PhD degrees.  We really appreciate National Science Foundation's kind support for this project.
